Award.AwardTitle: Coordination and Student Support for the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) Workshop; Fairbanks, Alaska; May 29-June 3, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provide support for the annual SuperDarn workshop to be held at the Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska in Fairbanks. The award would provide student travel support as well as other auxillary conference expenses including the expense required to enable visitors to visit the Poker Flat Rocket Range. This award is co-funded between the AGS-Aeronomy program and the PLR - Polar Programs (Antarctica), Astrophysics and Space Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) Workshop 2016 was held May 29 – June 3, 2016, in Fairbanks, Alaska. SuperDARN is an international global array of over 30 high frequency radars designed to observe dynamical plasma processes from mid-latitudes to the polar cap regions in both hemispheres. The SuperDARN Workshops are held annually and are hosted by SuperDARN partner organizations from over 10 countries. They bring together a broad spectrum of scientists, students, and engineers to discuss new research results in magnetospheric, ionospheric, and upper atmospheric physics, review technical and data analysis developments, and coordinate the network operations and sharing of the data.

The SuperDARN Workshop 2016 was hosted by the Geophysical Institute at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. This award provided partial support for student participation in the meeting, tour of the Poker Flat Research Range, essential logistical support for meeting coordination, and day-long Workshop session dedicated to the SuperDARN observations in the southern hemisphere.

50 participants from 9 countries (Australia, Canada, China, Japan, Norway, Japan, Italy, South Africa, UK, and USA) have attended the SuperDARN Workshop 2016 in Fairbanks, Alaska including 10 graduate students who have been supported by this award. 55 presentations have been made at the Workshop including 43 oral presentations and 12 poster presentations. The presentations covered a range of topics from technical aspects of radar operations to analysis of observations and modeling using SuperDARN data. Participants also visited the Poker Flat Research Range.

10 graduate students were supported by this award in their participation in the Workshop. The student travel support included registration fees and, for out-of-state students, lodging and airfare, for a total of up to $1890 per student. As a condition of this award, all students presented oral or poster papers at the Workshop. For most students this was their first opportunity to attend a SuperDARN workshop and present results of their research to the community. They were also exposed to presentations by working scientists in this area and were able to tour the Poker Flat Research Range.
